metadata.title: Self-healing soft electronics

sections.text:
Review ARticle https://doi.org/10.1038/s41928-019-0235-0
Department of Chemical Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA. *e-mail: zbao@stanford.edu
Electronic devices, which were once heavy and cumbersome, are now compact and mobile. Flexible and stretchable electronic devices are now also emerging1–3, which have potential applications in health monitoring, artificial skins and implantable bioelectronics, and could allow electronics to be seamlessly integrated into our everyday lives1–8. These devices have been developed through various design approaches, including strain engineering6, ultrathin nanomembranes9,10 and intrinsically soft polymers11,12. However, the approaches are not resistant to unexpected mechanical damage caused by repeated wear and tear and accidental cutting or scratching, which are the main causes of device failure6,10. As a result, researchers have looked to create electronic devices that can selfheal, and thus, like human skin1, can repair unexpected internal or external damages and recover critical functions.
In recent years, considerable progress has been made in the development of self-healable electronic materials13–16, which has led to their successful integration into functional electronic devices, including sensors, electronic skins, solar cells, field-effect transistors, dielectric actuators and energy devices. In this Review Article, we examine the advances in self-healable electronic devices that will deliver the next generation of soft electronics (Fig. 1). We first explore the different approaches for creating self-healable electronic materials. We then consider the use of self-healable electronic materials in the fabrication of functional components (insulators, conductors and semiconductors), devices (sensors, transistors and energy devices) and integrated systems. Finally, we discuss the challenges that exist in developing practical applications based on selfhealing soft electronics.

sections.heading: Artificial self-healing systems
sections.text:
Inspired by the autonomous wound-healing ability of human skin, artificial self-healing systems were initially designed to mimic these properties using clever polymer chemistry17–20. Self-healing polymers can be broadly classified into two types: extrinsic and intrinsic21. Extrinsic self-healing occurs when dispersed healing agents (or reagents) — typically consisting of reactive precursors and catalysts in a polymer matrix — are released after damage. These healing agents can then repair the wounded areas through autonomous polymerization reactions and the reconstruction of crosslinked networks (Fig. 2a). Although this approach is highly reliable, it unfortunately only allows the material to heal a limited number of times and usually cannot repeat healing at the same locations. In
contrast, intrinsic self-healing materials do not require the addition of healing reagents and the wounded regions are able to repeatedly heal (even at ambient conditions in some cases) through the reorganization of the polymer matrix. During this process, the polymer matrix is rebuilt from the regeneration of dynamic covalent or non-covalent bonds and the entanglement of polymer chains at the damaged interfaces (Fig. 2b). These intrinsically healable materials are usually soft (that is, they have a low elastic modulus) and deformable. As a result, intrinsically self-healable polymer materials have drawn significant attention in the development of selfhealable soft electronics.
In this section, we focus on progress in the creation of intrinsic self-healing polymers. Intrinsic self-healing capabilities in polymeric systems are based on two important features: the diffusion of polymer chains and the reformation of broken dynamic bonds. An intrinsically self-healing polymeric system typically has a low glass transition temperature, which enhances the movement of polymer chains, and abundant sites for dynamic interactions20, which could be based on hydrogen bonding22, metal–ligand interaction23, π–π stacking, hydrophobic interaction24, imine bonding25, disulfide bonding or boroxine bonding26. The mechanical properties of such a system can be tuned synthetically in various ways to meet requirements for applications. Some self-healing polymer systems can achieve autonomous healing at room temperature, whereas others can even heal in water after sustaining mechanical damage.
Despite significant progress in developing self-healing chemistry, only a limited number of self-healing polymeric systems have been employed in electronic applications. This may be due to the multitude of requirements of such applications (including combining mechanical and electrical properties, electrical and environmental stability, and scalability) and a lack of understanding of the necessary design rules. Nonetheless, several research groups have recently reported strategies towards engineering mechanically tough elastomers with reliable and repeatable self-healing properties, and some of these elastomers have shown considerable potential for building self-healable soft electronic systems27,28.
Mechanisms of self-healing in electronic materials The self-healing process of electronically active polymeric materials is due to the dynamic equilibrium of the cross-linking network and percolation pathways in the polymeric system. sections.heading: Jiheong Kang, Jeffrey B.-H. Tok and Zhenan Bao *
sections.text:
Biological systems have the powerful ability to self-heal. Human skin can, for example, autonomously heal from wounds of various degrees, allowing it to restore its mechanical and electrical properties. In contrast, human-made electronic devices degrade over time due to fatigue, corrosion or damage incurred during operation, leading to device failure. Self-healing chemistry has emerged in recent years as a promising method for constructing soft electronic materials that are mechanically robust and can self-repair. Here we review the development of self-healing electronic materials and examine how such materials can be used to fabricate self-healing electronic devices. We explore the potential new functionalities of self-healing electronic systems that would not typically be possible with conventional electronic systems and discuss the current challenges in delivering selfhealing soft electronics for practical applications.

In some cases, solvent vapour is also needed to activate polymer chains to undergo rearrangements12. Owing to the low conductivity of polymeric materials, design strategies for creating self-healing and high-performance electronic materials have mainly focused on incorporating electronically active fillers into a dynamic polymer matrix. We have, for example, recently shown that the nanostructured conductive networks based on one-dimensional wires, in contact with a crosslinked self-healing polymer matrix, can be dynamically rearranged to allow the recovery of its original percolation paths for electrical conduction after mechanical damage29 (Fig. 3c). The size and surface properties of the conductive fillers in a polymer matrix may affect both the kinetics of self-healing and the electrical responses.
It is important to distinguish between mechanically tough selfhealing materials and flowable viscoelastic materials, as highly flowable viscoelastic materials can be used as the polymer matrix for self-healable electronics as well. In flowable viscoelastic materials, the healing is mainly due to the intermixing of the materials at the ‘reconnected interface’, whereas in self-healing materials, the recovery of broken cross-linking bonds occurs in addition to inter-mixing. Flowable viscoelastic materials have the drawback of undergoing essentially permanent plastic deformation, even after a mechanical force is applied. In particular, even though interfaces can be reconnected by external forces or intrinsic flowability, these viscoelastic materials are not able to restore their original properties. In contrast, combining both strong and weak dynamic bonding can result in elastic, yet tough self-healing materials.
The property of elasticity can assist in both efficient and autonomous self-healing recovery processes. One prominent effect of elasticity on the self-healing process can be observed in leaves, which can close wounds rapidly with the help of stored elastic stress built within their underlying structure30. Inspired by leaves, a recent demonstration of a self-healing polymeric system experimentally confirmed the importance of elasticity for the self-healing process by controlling its internal microstructures31. In this regard, mechanically tough self-healing materials will be more suitable for fabricating robust electronics than highly flowable viscoelastic materials.
The high toughness of human skin and the high interfacial toughness of tendons and cartilage to bone are all due to the selfrecoverable energy dissipation systems in our body32. Highly
stretchable and tough hydrogel materials, as well as tough interfaces with diverse surfaces including glass, metals and polymers, were previously created by employing self-healing hydrated polymer networks that dissipate energy33,34. We have also recently demonstrated a tough self-healing elastomer with dual-strength hydrogenbonding sites as cross-links27. Such materials can sustain large applied strain, even when a notch is intentionally introduced27,28.
Self-healing functionalities in electronic materials The dynamic cross-linking bonds responsible for self-healing properties can be optimized to provide additional useful properties to self-healing materials. In addition, breaking such bonds by mechanical loadings is a mechanism for energy dissipation, which can then improve both the fracture toughness of the corresponding elastomer and interface toughness with other layers.
A tough, self-healing elastomer is an ideal carrier material for soft electronics, especially those subjected to significant wear and tear over time. A carrier material with high toughness is tolerant to damages or small cracks, and can thus significantly delay crack propagation. For example, a film with high fracture toughness can be efficiently sutured on soft animal skin or tissue without rupturing27. In contrast, commonly used soft substrates for biomedical applications, such as covalently cross-linked polydimethylsiloxane, can easily tear around the sutured location due to their intrinsic low fracture toughness.
Multifunctional electronic systems have numerous interfaces, such as those between the device and the substrate and those between layers. The differences in surface chemistry and mechanical properties of each layer can easily result in device failure due to delamination under strain. If all of the components are based on similar self-healing polymer networks, they can subsequently be seamlessly integrated into a single system through the self-bonding (the formation of dynamic bonds at interfaces between layers) of the self-healing polymer, making the entire system mechanically robust29. Thus, this self-bonding property can be important for the efficient fabrication of three-dimensional-configured electronic devices35.

After cutting the wires, the current flow could be re-established and the mechanical properties could be recovered once the severed edges were physically re-assembled. Self-healing polymers have also been tested as dielectric layers. However, most of the self-healing polymers to date are based on hydrophilic hydrogen bonds or metal–ligand interactions, and they tend to absorb moisture and become unstable under high electric fields36 (for this reason, they are rarely used as dielectric layers). Recently, the toughness of selfhealable cross-linked networks has been tuned through suitable molecular design and rational selection of metal–ligand bonds and counter ions. This approach also led to the fabrication of materials with stable dielectric properties without measurable ionic effects, even at low frequencies37. Furthermore, water-insensitive tough self-healing polymeric systems were recently demonstrated to be highly promising as dielectric materials27,38.
Conductors. Conducting materials are essential for the development of electronic devices, including sensors, displays, actuators, circuits and energy storage devices. Therefore, self-healing conductors have been extensively studied in the past few years. Important parameters that need to be optimized are conductivity, mechanical strength recovery after mechanical damage and autonomous self-healing. Mechanical self-healing is achieved when a mechanically damaged cross-linking network (through cutting, tearing or scratching) is able to efficiently recover its original network, usually through the reformation of the broken bonds and intermixing of polymer chains (Fig. 3c). The self-healing efficiency can be determined from the restoration of properties such as fracture strain and its corresponding tensile stress. The kinetics of mechanical selfhealing can be readily investigated and tuned by tailoring molecular structures, controlling microstructures and changing temperature. In contrast, electrical self-healing has two distinct steps: first, the conductive pathways can be re-established quickly just by physical contact between two damaged surfaces (Fig. 3d) and second, they are
dynamically reconstructed to recover their original mechanical and electrical properties. To date, most of the existing self-healable conductive materials have focused on the instantaneous recovery of the conductive pathways on physical contact, which can potentially be achieved by using a soft conductive material. However, the conductive material must be rendered ‘dynamic’ to be able to also recover the original mechanical properties (Fig. 3c,d). Our recent work has indicated that the dynamic nature of a self-healing polymer that is in contact with a conductive network consisting of nanomaterials can facilitate the recovery of both electrical and mechanical properties29. Such conductive self-healing composites were prepared by combining a dynamically cross-linked polymer network with conductive nanofillers (for example, metallic nanoparticles, metallic nanowires39, carbon nanotubes or graphene). When the nanofiller was mixed with the self-healing polymer matrix, the conductivity of the composite was typically quite poor and unstable, limiting their applications. For practical applications, the conductivity of selfhealing composites needs to be further improved40.
By embedding patterned silver nanowire (AgNW) lines within a tough self-healing polymer, mechanically tough self-healing conductive lines and patterns can be prepared29. Interestingly, though AgNW lines that have been cut cannot effectively establish reconnection, the dynamic reconstruction of the conductive network is possible: the dynamic nature of the self-healing polymer matrix can facilitate the conductive lines to autonomously recover their original electrical properties and mechanical properties. For example, a completely cut conductive line can be again stretched up to 100% strain while retaining high conductivity, after autonomous selfhealing at room temperature. The phenomenon of reorganization of the conducting nanostructures after cutting was also observed for carbon nanotubes (CNTs)29 and silver flakes as the conductive nanofillers. This implies that stretchable self-healing conductive (and potentially semiconducting) materials can be made, even when the nanoelectronic materials cannot self-heal by themselves mechanically or electrically. It thus significantly broadens the range of approaches available to create self-healing electronic materials.
An ionic conductor is another emerging functional component for soft electronic applications41. It has shown considerable promise in stretchable ionic devices such as actuators, loud speakers42, transparent touch panels43 and ionic skin44. Many ionic conductors, such as hydrogels containing electrolytes and polymer gels swollen with ionic liquids, are intrinsically stretchable and transparent. A transparent, stretchable ionic conductor with autonomous self-healing ability has recently been reported45. This polymeric material is composed of a polar, stretchable polymer chain such as poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) and an ionic liquid. The polymer chains in the material interact with the ionic liquid through strong ion–dipole interactions to form a self-healable cross-linked network, which exhibits reasonable ionic conductivity. Furthermore, this type of material can be used to build touch, pressure and strain sensors capable of self-healing in aquatic environments46.
Semiconductors. Semiconductors are essential elements for building diodes and field-effect transistors (FETs). However, making a semiconducting layer self-healable, while also maintaining good charge transport, is extremely challenging. In particular, because the semiconducting layer for most devices is usually very thin (<100 nm), it is difficult to align the damaged areas properly for full healing. Moreover, polymer semiconductors are usually semicrystalline and have high glass transition temperatures. These properties result in essentially ‘frozen’ polymer chains at room temperature. Selfhealing can take place even in thin polymer semiconducting layers that have hydrogen-bonding moieties. Specifically, nanosized cracks formed by fatigue in such a polymer semiconducting film have been found to heal by solvent annealing and thermal annealing, allowing efficient recovery of its charge carrier mobility and stretchability12.

Self-healing functional electronic devices Self-healing electronic materials can be integrated into functional electronic and electrochemical devices including sensors, FETs and energy storage devices.
Sensors. Sensors are widely employed in our daily lives to detect physical (for example, pressure, strain, light, heat, humidity) or chemical signals47. Self-healing sensors can potentially increase the lifespan of such devices for both functional (such as sensing ability) and aesthetic purposes. Most reported self-healable electronic sensors rely on the changes of their conductive pathways by external stimuli for their sensing function. Initial demonstrations of self-healable sensors were made using a piezo-resistive self-healing composite (usually a mixture of μNi microparticles and a self-healing polymeric material) as the active material48. This material is both pressure and flexion sensitive due to the change in μNi microparticle spacing when external mechanical forces are applied (which results in a sizeable electrical resistance change). It can therefore detect both a hand shake and arm bending when laminated onto the palm and the elbow, respectively. In addition to μNi microparticles, carbon particles and graphene can be also used in pressure and flexion sensors49,50.
A capacitive touch screen was also constructed by laminating two AgNW-based, self-healable polymer composite layers patterned in rows and columns51. An active electrode was then coupled with a neighbouring ground electrode to form a capacitor. Consequently, capacitance changes occurred when a finger was in contact with the electrodes. After sustaining mechanical damage, the touch screen was able to recover its touch sensing function by heating to 80 ºC for 30 s to restore its conductive pathways.
Self-healable temperature sensors can be fabricated by incorporating ionic liquid into a microfluidic channel embedded in a self-healable polymer matrix52. Because the ionic conductivity of an ionic liquid
increases at higher temperature, the changes in the ion conductivity of the composite film can be used for temperature sensing. This concept was further expanded to a self-healing near-infrared sensor, which was fabricated by loading modified carbon nanotubes capable of efficient photothermal conversion in the ionic liquid. The resultant nearinfrared sensor also exhibited repeatable self-healing properties52.
Humidity and chemical gas sensor devices with self-healing properties have also been made based on the hybridization of surface-modified CNTs and hydrophilic self-healing materials53. When hydrophilic self-healing polymers were used, the composites showed moisture absorption capacity. As a result, the resistance of the polymer composites responded to moisture changes in the environment. A transparent CNT network coated with polyelectrolyte multilayers was found to specifically respond to only NH3, compared with other volatile organic compounds. It also showed repeatable healability of its sensing performance.
Transistors. Organic field-effect transistors (OFETs) have been successfully integrated in sensors, memory devices and in the driving circuits for displays. Nowadays, multiple organic and polymer semiconductors have exhibited field-effect mobilities exceeding 1 cm2 V–1 s–1, similar to the performance of amorphous silicon thinfilm transistors. Since OFETs are moving towards printable, flexible and even stretchable electronics, they are more susceptible to mechanical damages such as rubbing and scratching. To realize selfhealable OFETs, three self-healable components need to be developed concurrently: semiconductors; dielectrics; and source, drain and gates. Individual bulk components with self-healing ability have already been developed and their electrical performances are sufficient to be integrated in OFETs. For example, electrically stable, self-healable dielectric layers have been created by incorporating metal–ligand bonds as cross-linking sites into a non-polar polymer matrix37. By choosing suitable counter anions, these layers did not exhibit double-layer capacitive effects caused by mobile ions, which resulted in OFETs with hysteresis-free transfer characteristics.

Self-healing electrodes based on CNTs and AgNWs have also been used to make source, drain and gate components29. However, it is still technically challenging to fabricate fully self-healable OFETs due to difficulties in the tedious fabrication process and limited self-healing properties of dielectrics and semiconductors in bulk or thick films. For OFETs, it is thus more practical to self-heal the nanosized cracks formed from fatigue.
Energy devices. Energy storage devices are necessary for the operation of electronic devices. An early example of a self-healable supercapacitor was fabricated by simply laminating acid-treated CNTs films onto a self-healing substrate composed of TiO2 nanoflowers and a self-healing polymer54. A polyvinyl pyrrolidone–H2SO4 gel was used for both self-healable electrolyte and separator components. The as-prepared flexible supercapacitors exhibited good electrochemical performance with self-healing capability (85.7% recovery in specific capacitance), even after cutting it for the fifth time. In another example, a wire-shaped self-healing supercapacitor was built using the same self-healing polymer. The electrode was prepared by mixing an aligned graphene sheet, AgNWs and a CNT network in fibres55. Performance was observed to be recovered by 92% on self-healing at room temperature. Another interesting approach based on using magnetic force for the reconnection and alignment of the broken wires has also been proposed. Here, a yarn-based supercapacitor was produced by covering a self-healable polyurethane shell with magnetic microparticles56. Up to approximately 72% of the specific capacitance could be recovered after four repeated cutting-and-healing cycles. New conductive inks containing ferromagnetic particles have also been developed and used to fabricate magnetically self-healable electrochemical devices57. A self-healing perovskite solar cell was created through the incorporation of polyethylene glycol chains in the active layer58. Self-healing electronic active layers and devices are summarized in Fig. 4.
Self-healing integrated electronic systems All the devices described above are only partially self-healable, as only the active material in the device can undergo self-healing. A fully self-healable flexible sensor device with multicomponents was only recently reported57. All parts in this chemresistor, including
substrate, electrode and active layer, were self-healing and the device was able to sense pressure and strain, as well as detecting volatile organic compounds59.
Another example of a fully self-healing electronic system is a multifunctional integrated electronic skin using a mechanically tough and autonomously self-healable semitransparent electrode29 (Fig. 5a). This electronic skin was constructed with an electrocardiogram (ECG) sensor for electromyography (EMG), strain sensors and a light-emitting capacitor (LEC), so that it can effectively monitor physiological signals and display feedback information through closedloop communication between the user and electronics. Furthermore, every part (including interconnects) was autonomously self-healable and stretchable up to 100%. For example, the standalone LEC can completely be healed to recover its original mechanical and electrical properties, even after suffering a complete cut. After healing, the LEC was observed to continue emitting light even at 100% strain.
Realizing self-healing in electronic devices with multilayer structures is extremely difficult because each layer has different mechanical properties, and it is challenging to achieve perfect alignment between different layers in the multilayer stack when they are mechanically cut. However, if each layer has high inherent toughness, it will be easier to achieve better alignment with high yield. We note that high toughness may also contribute to a much cleaner and less-deformed surface when a layer is mechanically cut. In particular, in materials that are not mechanically tough, mechanical damages will result in significant permanent plastic deformation (especially on the surfaces), which will make it difficult to effectively reconnect the damaged surfaces through the self-healing process. In addition, high toughness will impart a ‘shape memory’ effect to system, hence promoting the autonomous self-healing process31.
Modular and reconfigurable integrated electronic systems Self-healing chemistry is not only useful for building mechanically robust and durable electronics, but also opens up opportunities for constructing soft electronics in unique ways. For example, we recently demonstrated the concept of stretchable modular and reconfigurable electronic systems60, in which multiple electronic modules are electrically interconnected and can digitally communicate with each other (Fig. 5b). The conductive interconnects were fabricated on a tough, stretchable, self-healable substrate, which allowed the components to be cut, reconfigured and reconnected. Each module had multiple self-healing conductive lines and could readily interconnect with each other via the self-healing process. With this approach, two modular electronic systems based on non-return to zero and inter-integrated circuit digital communication protocols were demonstrated.
Existing soft electronics are not malleable, intuitively programmable or adaptable to rapidly changing social and mechanical norms, due to their inherent mechanical stiffness and lack of freedom for user design and construction. In contrast, modular electronics using self-healing interconnecting technologies with inherent flexibility and stretchability could allow flexible positioning of modules on three-dimensional surfaces and structures, thus offering a variety of skin electronic design possibilities.
outlook Self-healing soft electronics materials and devices have progressed rapidly in recent years. However, several challenges need to be addressed before such electronic devices can be seamlessly integrated into our daily life.
Fabrication. In general, the fabrication processes of self-healing materials are incompatible with existing electronic technologies. In particular, patterning self-healing materials with the small feature sizes required for integrated electronics applications remains challenging and tedious. Therefore, the development of photo-patternable or self-healing electronics materials will be necessary.
Properties. Despite the exciting developments in the field, the availability of functional materials for applications remains limited, especially semiconductors and conductors. Furthermore, the electronic properties of current self-healable devices are not yet comparable to non-healable functional electronic devices. New design concepts
for self-healing electronic polymers or hybridization of self-healing polymers with high-performance inorganic nanomaterials will be necessary to improve their electronic properties.
Process. It should also be noted that the healing process remains relatively slow and non-autonomous. Specifically, heating, light exposure or solvents are needed for the rapid healing of some materials and devices. Therefore, the development of an autonomous self-healing system like a human body would be ideal. In addition, the development of an on-demand self-healing system, which allows the selective triggering of the self-healing process in designated locations, will be useful in integrated electronic systems.
Large-area. When the size of damages is larger than the thickness of layers, it is challenging to realize an efficient self-healing process. Therefore, the self-healing process is currently limited to only small-area damages.
Thermal stability. As most intrinsic self-healing polymers are based on dynamic non-covalent cross-linked bonds, their mechanical properties are sensitive to temperature. Therefore, their thermal stability is potentially poor. Strategies to construct thermodynamically stable self-healing systems will help to make them more reliable and stable.
Self-healing chemistry is a valuable approach to constructing soft electronics as if offers self-bonding, as well as functionalities such as robustness, modularity and reconfigurability. The resulting self-healing soft electronics are of potential use in wearable electronics and bioelectronics applications due to their ability to accommodate varying external strains caused by dynamic movement. The materials could also be of use in the development of more stable batteries, where they could, for example, act as silicon anode binders59 and lithium metal coatings61. Self-healing materials will, we believe, help deliver the next-generation of soft electronics.

metadata.abstractText: Department of Chemical Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA. *e-mail: zbao@stanford.edu Electronic devices, which were once heavy and cumbersome, are now compact and mobile. Flexible and stretchable electronic devices are now also emerging1–3, which have potential applications in health monitoring, artificial skins and implantable bioelectronics, and could allow electronics to be seamlessly integrated into our everyday lives1–8. These devices have been developed through various design approaches, including strain engineering6, ultrathin nanomembranes9,10 and intrinsically soft polymers11,12. However, the approaches are not resistant to unexpected mechanical damage caused by repeated wear and tear and accidental cutting or scratching, which are the main causes of device failure6,10. As a result, researchers have looked to create electronic devices that can selfheal, and thus, like human skin1, can repair unexpected internal or external damages and recover critical functions. In recent years, considerable progress has been made in the development of self-healable electronic materials13–16, which has led to their successful integration into functional electronic devices, including sensors, electronic skins, solar cells, field-effect transistors, dielectric actuators and energy devices. In this Review Article, we examine the advances in self-healable electronic devices that will deliver the next generation of soft electronics (Fig. 1). We first explore the different approaches for creating self-healable electronic materials. We then consider the use of self-healable electronic materials in the fabrication of functional components (insulators, conductors and semiconductors), devices (sensors, transistors and energy devices) and integrated systems. Finally, we discuss the challenges that exist in developing practical applications based on selfhealing soft electronics.
